Award.AwardTitle: Long range orientation correlation in liquids
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor David Shelton of the University of Nevada Las Vegas will conduct a series of nonlinear laser light scattering experiments to probe the structure of molecular liquids. Contrary to the generally accepted view that intermolecular position and orientation correlations in liquids extend at most a few molecular diameters, second-harmonic light scattering reveals molecular orientation correlation at distances of tens to hundreds of molecular diameters in many liquids. The polarization dependence of second harmonic light scattering provides a uniquely sensitive probe of long-range polar molecular order. This study aims to measure the strength, range and form of the long-range molecular orientation correlations in liquids, and to gain an understanding of the origin and consequences of these correlations.

Liquids and systems of nanometer scale are of wide importance and current interest in physics, chemistry and biology. A wide range of basic and applied chemical research will be impacted by the results of this investigation of previously unobserved structure at the nanometer scale in many common liquids including water. Graduate and undergraduate students will participate in this research, and will be trained in state-of-the-art laser light scattering techniques.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The interaction between molecules possessing a dipole moment extends to long range, and is sensitive to the relative orientation of the molecules at all distances. Systems where structure is influenced by this long range dipolar interaction, of importance in physics, chemistry and biology, include liquids composed of dipolar molecules and proteins composed of polar residues. However, absence of order beyond the nearest neighbors of each molecule is inferred from previous measurements of the scattering angle and light polarization dependence for light scattered from simple molecular liquids. The apparent absence of order is due to the insensitivity of the technique. The long-range intermolecular correlations in polar liquids have been observed and studied in this project, using a second harmonic light scattering technique which is uniquely sensitive to long-range orientation correlations.

 The angle and polarization dependence of second harmonic light scattering from polar liquids that is observed in this work cannot be explained by assuming only short range correlations between the molecules in the liquid. In fact, the observed angle and polarization dependence requires that the orientation correlations vary precisely as r^-3 at long range, which points to electrostatic interactions between the molecular dipoles as the mechanism enforcing the correlations. This conclusion is supported by evidence from large scale molecular dynamics simulations for these liquids. The dipole-dipole orientation correlation strength calculated at the largest intermolecular distance in the simulation, about 20 molecular diameters, is in agreement with the long-range orientation correlation strength determined from the experimental measurements. The experimental observations show effects of orientation correlations between molecules separated by more than 1000 molecular diameters in liquids such as nitrobenzene, acetonitrile and water.

 This project has provided research opportunities in chemical physics and training in nonlinear optical and laser spectroscopy techniques for undergraduate and graduate students.
